docs.lead_paragraph: For the sixth consecutive year, the raises that American workers receive have been smaller, or no higher, than those of the year before, according to 1995 figures released today by the Labor Department. The 2.9 percent increase in overall compensation last year, the skimpiest since at least 1980, was just enough to keep workers ahead of inflation, which at the consumer level ran at a 2.5 percent pace.

headline.main: Index of Pay and Benefits Rose 2.9% in '95

docs.lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Hospital Association said its members have already provided $60 million in unreimbursed care to poor patients since funds set aside for charity care ran out Dec. 31. Three Democratic Assembly members, led by Neil M. Cohen of Elizabeth, the deputy minority leader, said they had come up with a solution to the crisis and would propose today that $200 million for charity-care reimbursements be made available from the state's general fund. But Assemblyman Walter J. Kavanaugh, a Somerville Republican who chairs the Appropriations Committee, said he prefers to use money from the state's Unemployment Insurance Fund, while reducing the cost of charity care.

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Proposals for Charity Care

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST a small fraction of the millions of people who are dependent on alcohol and illegal drugs get help from their doctors, a national panel of experts has concluded. The panel, which consisted of 45 doctors, insurance company representatives, public officials, business leaders and leaders of medical education, found that most primary-care doctors lacked both the training and the desire to diagnose addictions, even though recent widespread changes in health insurance coverage have shifted more of the burden of doing so onto them.

headline.main: Doctors Found to Fail in Diagnosing Addictions

docs.lead_paragraph: The Gannett Company said today that it had agreed to sell its Louis Harris & Associates polling unit to the Gordon S. Black Corporation, also a provider of polling and marketing services. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline.main: Gannett to Sell Its Polling Unit To Competitor

docs.snippet: The Gannett Company said today that it had agreed to sell its Louis Harris &  Associates polling unit to the Gordon S. Black Corporation, also a provider of polling and marketing services.         Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

docs.lead_paragraph: It began in 1910 as an effort by society matrons to help bedraggled horses on the Manhattan docks and became the world's largest pet hospital. This self-described Mayo Clinic for Animals treated everything from a puppy that swallowed a 12-inch knife to an 800-pound circus tiger, using technology only slightly behind that of advanced human hospitals. But the vast ambitions of the Animal Medical Center, a nine-story complex at 510 East 62d Street whose board includes social heavyweights like William E. Simon and Barbara Walters, are being sorely tested. In a statement issued last week in response to several highly critical articles in The New York Post charging mismanagement and declining standards of care, hospital officials said the center faced "a very difficult fiscal crisis." The hospital reported an operating loss of $3 million last year, double that of five years ago, as a result of sharply rising costs, an inability to push fees any higher and, most important, problems with people not paying their bills.

headline.main: Troubles Are All Too Human;At Pet Hospital, Fiscal Woes and Stormy Relations

docs.lead_paragraph: To judge by the numbers, these are expansive days for Christian radio. Two decades after evangelical Protestant voters emerged as a force in national politics, conservative Christian broadcasters are continuing to carve out a greater share of the radio market. Last year, the number of radio stations broadcasting 15 or more hours of weekly religious programming rose 10 percent to 1,463, said the National Religious Broadcasters, a trade association in Manassas, Va. That total was nearly double the number 15 years ago.

headline.main: Number of Religious Broadcasters Continues to Grow

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 9 O'CLOCK ONE RECENT morning, an emergency gong resounded throughout Bellevue Hospital. Members of the medical staff raced through hallways and down littered back stairwells toward the emergency room. "Get them to send some boot covers down from the O.R.!" a doctor called out. The cramped space, crowded with residents yelling and hauling equipment, resembled the engine room of a submarine. Oxygen tanks were piled by the door. Canisters of atropine, a drug used to control muscle spasms, were stacked in metal carts. Everyone donned blue plastic coats, masks with Plexiglas shields, rubber gloves and boot covers, then turned toward the emergency-room door, waiting for casualties to barrel through. This was only a drill. The staff was bracing to treat victims of a simulated sarin-gas attack on the New York subway system like the one that terrified Tokyo last March. Every six months, emergency personnel descend on Bellevue to test the city's response system. Each time the script changes to keep pace with natural disasters and terrorist innovations. In 1993, only minutes after the World Trade Center exploded, the same gong sounded for real as 110 critically injured patients were rushed to the emergency room. During today's drill the staff fell silent as a doctor ran in from the ambulance bay. "Our victims are getting cold," he said. "Can we bring out 10 blankets?"

docs.lead_paragraph: LATER this year, employees of the Equitable Life Assurance Company will start moving into 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Olympia & York's huge building on 52d Street. Physically, some will just trek across the street, while others will come from a few neighborhoods away. Metaphorically, they will travel much farther. This move brings Equitable full circle in a long, eventful real-estate odyssey. The 137-year-old insurer has owned and occupied some of the city's biggest, most modern buildings. Now, other companies will occupy Equitable Center, the lavish monument Equitable built itself a decade ago. It will be a tenant, albeit the major one, in a more utilitarian building that someone else owns.

headline.main: Commercial Property/Equitable Life's Switch;A Short Move, but to a Wholly Different Mindset
